section.title: Monte Carlo Exercises
section.p: For each HW problem, include a well-labelled plot that shows the shapes and the points selected through the Monte Carlo process.

li.p:
Area of a circle
Find the area of the unit circle by putting it in a larger square with corners at (\pm 2, \pm 2) and using the fact that the bigger square has area 16. Compare with the correct answer, found using a geometrical argument.

Area of a hexagon
Find the area of the regular hexagon inscribed in the unit circle by putting it in a larger square with corners at (\pm 2, \pm 2) and using the fact that the bigger square has area 16. Compare with the correct answer, found using a geometrical argument.

Areas of sections of overlapping figures
Find the areas of the three regions that are created by the unit circle and the square with corners at (-0.5,-0.5), (1.5,-0.5), (1.5,1.5), (-0.5,1.5). Put both figures in a larger square with corners at (\pm 2, \pm 2) and use the fact that the bigger square has area 16. Compare with the correct answers, found using geometrical arguments or calculus.

Area under a simple curve
Find the area under the curve y = x^2+2 from x = 0 to x = B, where B is input by the user. The larger square (or perhaps rectangle) will now have to be found in terms of B. For a few values of B of your choice, compare the area with the correct answer, found using calculus.

Area under the normal curve
Find the area under the normal curve of mean 0 and standard deviation 1 from x = A to x = B where A and B are input by the user. The larger square (or perhaps rectangle) will now have to be found in terms of A and B. You may assume that A<B and both are between -4 and 4. Conclusions
What can you say about the Monte Carlo method in its use for finding areas?
